elements.content: Employing a V-shaped rigid multicarboxylate ligand 1,3-di­(2′,5′-dicarboxypheny)­benzene acid (H4L), three microporous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), H2[Co4(O)­L2(H2O)2]·3DMA·8H2O (1), H3[Zn2.5L2]·NMP·5H2O (2), and H3[Cd2.5L2]·4DMF·3H2O (3) were synthesized and characterized. Compound 1 exhibits a cage-based (3,6)-connected rtl topological MOF with [Co4O­(COO)8] clusters and highly selective adsorption of CO2 over CH4. Compounds 2 and 3 are isostructural and display a rare 4,8-connected flu net with linear trinuclear [Zn3(COO)6] clusters. Interestingly, when compound 3 was soaked in DMF solution containing Eu3+ ions, an Eu-loaded compound Eu@3 with bright red fluorescence was obtained, which reveals highly selective sensing for Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2– ions. This represents an unusual example to achieve the detection of Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2– ions simultaneously by fluorescence spectrometry based on a recyclable Eu-loaded MOF sensor.

elements.content: Four 3D metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) based on a V-shaped tetracarboxylate ligand have been synthesized and characterized; 1 reveals high selective adsorption for CO2 over CH4, while Eu@3 as a luminescent sensor can selectively and sensitively detect Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2− ions.

elements.content: As with rapid industrial development and other anthropogenic processes, the environmental pollution resulted from the increased release of hazardous waste into the environment has become a persistent threat to human health. Cu2+ and Fe3+ ions as two kinds of essential trace elements in the human body play vital roles in the areas of environmental, biological, and chemical systems. Both deficiency and overload of the two elements may cause some types of severe diseases, such as hematological manifestations, iron-deficiency anemia, and so on. At the same time, Cr2O7 2– ion as the important industrial source incurs human lots of health problems due to its strong oxidizability and toxicity. Therefore, a material with selectivity and sensitivity for monitoring these ions is required. The luminescent probes owing to the high sensitivity, easy operation, and rapid response time are considered ideal alternative for sensing and detecting pollutants. In this connection, lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs), a new type of crystalline porous material employed as chemical sensors, have been extensively studied due to strong luminescence and permanent porosity that offer an ideal environment to accommodate substrates and realize improved sensitivity as well. The hot issue of fluorescence sensing was focused on detection of toxic ions or small organic molecules. Although a few Ln-MOFs exhibit good potential in sensing Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2– ions, however, only few examples were observed to show luminescent sensing for two of these ions, and no example reveals sensing for these three ions simultaneously (Table S1). Notably, the most known Ln-MOF sensors were usually synthesized by the direction reaction of Ln3+ ions and organic ligands. An alternative method is the postsynthetic loading of Ln3+ ions into the anionic MOFs based on transition metal ions through the cationic exchange. The latter method would have great prospects because of the large number of existing elective anionic MOFs. However, the related Ln-MOF sensors obtained through the postsynthetic loading of Ln3+ ions into MOFs were rarely reported.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As with rapid industrial development and other anthropogenic processes, the environmental pollution resulted from the increased release of hazardous waste into the environment has become a persistent threat to human health. Cu2+ and Fe3+ ions as two kinds of essential trace elements in the human body play vital roles in the areas of environmental, biological, and chemical systems. Both deficiency and overload of the two elements may cause some types of severe diseases, such as hematological manifestations, iron-deficiency anemia, and so on. At the same time, Cr2O7 2- ion as the important industrial source incurs human lots of health problems due to its strong oxidizability and toxicity. Therefore, a material with selectivity and sensitivity for monitoring these ions is required. The luminescent probes owing to the high sensitivity, easy operation, and rapid response time are considered ideal alternative for sensing and detecting pollutants. In this connection, lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs), a new type of crystalline porous material employed as chemical sensors, have been extensively studied due to strong luminescence and permanent porosity that offer an ideal environment to accommodate substrates and realize improved sensitivity as well. The hot issue of fluorescence sensing was focused on detection of toxic ions or small organic molecules. Although a few Ln-MOFs exhibit good potential in sensing Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2- ions, however, only few examples were observed to show luminescent sensing for two of these ions, and no example reveals sensing for these three ions simultaneously (Table S1). Notably, the most known Ln-MOF sensors were usually synthesized by the direction reaction of Ln3+ ions and organic ligands. An alternative method is the postsynthetic loading of Ln3+ ions into the anionic MOFs based on transition metal ions through the cationic exchange. The latter method would have great prospects because of the large number of existing elective anionic MOFs. However, the related Ln-MOF sensors obtained through the postsynthetic loading of Ln3+ ions into MOFs were rarely reported.

elements.content: Anthropogenic CO2 emissions to the atmosphere are presently one of the most urgent climate issues. Carbon capture and storage (CCs) technology for declining or eliminating CO2 from flue stream and natural and fuel gases to minimize the influence of CO2 has intrigued researchers in recent years. MOFs due to the adjustable pore structures, multiple active sites, and so on have been proposed as promising porous materials for CO2 capture.
elements.clean_text: Anthropogenic CO2 emissions to the atmosphere are presently one of the most urgent climate issues. Carbon capture and storage (CCs) technology for declining or eliminating CO2 from flue stream and natural and fuel gases to minimize the influence of CO2 has intrigued researchers in recent years. MOFs due to the adjustable pore structures, multiple active sites, and so on have been proposed as promising porous materials for CO2 capture.

elements.content: To reach the dual functions of MOFs in luminescent sensing for ions and CO2 capture, we are interested in the V-shaped rigid multicarboxylate ligands, which have been proved to be ideal candidates for building MOFs based on cluster second building units (SBUs) with structural rigidity and porosity because of their rich coordination modes and the ability of forming versatile porous frameworks. In this work, we chose a V-shaped rigid tetracarboxylate ligand, 1,3-di­(2′,5′-dicarboxypheny)­benzene acid (H4L) (), wherein four carboxylic groups were spaced by three phenyl rings to form a symmetrical spatial configuration. Herein, three new porous MOFs, H2[Co4(O)­L2(H2O)2]·3DMA·8H2O (1), H3[Zn2.5L2]·NMP·5H2O (2), and H3[Cd2.5L2]·4DMF·3H2O (3), were constructed. Compound 1 with (3,6)-connected rtl topology based on [Co4O­(COO)8] clusters exhibits highly selective CO2 capture over CH4. Compounds 2, 3, and the Eu-loaded 3 (Eu@3) are isostructural with rare 4,8-connected flu network based on trinuclear clusters. Interestingly, Eu@3 with bright red luminescence displays selective and sensitive fluorescent probes for Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2– ions simultaneously.

elements.content: All the starting materials and reagents used in the experiment were commercially obtained. Infrared (IR) spectra were obtained through an EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer together with a KBr pellet from 4000 to 400 cm–1. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed through a Perkin-Elemer 2400C Elemental Analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a N2 stream using a Netzsch TG209F3 instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Sorption isotherms were measured by a Micrometrics ASAP 2020M. Luminescent spectra were measured on an Edinburgh FLS55 luminescence spectrometer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy was performed on an Agilent 725 ICP-OES spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the starting materials and reagents used in the experiment were commercially obtained. Infrared (IR) spectra were obtained through an EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer together with a KBr pellet from 4000 to 400 cm-1. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed through a Perkin-Elemer 2400C Elemental Analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a N2 stream using a Netzsch TG209F3 instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Sorption isotherms were measured by a Micrometrics ASAP 2020M. Luminescent spectra were measured on an Edinburgh FLS55 luminescence spectrometer. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy was performed on an Agilent 725 ICP-OES spectrometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0291 g, 0.1 mmol), H4L (0.0203 g, 0.05 mmol), DMA (3 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL) was sealed in a 10 mL glass bottle. The bottle was heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C min–1. Purple block crystals of 1 were obtained in 50.4% yield. Anal. A mixture of 3 (0.143 g, 0.1 mmol), Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.045 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and CH3CN (0.5 mL) was sealed in a 10 mL glass bottle. elements.content: A Bruker Smart CCD area-detector was utilized to get the crystal data of compounds 1–3 at 296(2) K using ω rotation scans with widths of 0.3° and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 with the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were added to their geometrically ideal positions. The contribution to scattering from water molecules was subtracted by using the SQUEEZE routine in the PLATON program. Relevant crystallographic data were given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles were listed in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Measurements

A Bruker Smart CCD area-detector was utilized to get the crystal data of compounds 1-3 at 296(2) K using ω rotation scans with widths of 0.3° and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 with the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were added to their geometrically ideal positions. The contribution to scattering from water molecules was subtracted by using the SQUEEZE routine in the PLATON program. Relevant crystallographic data were given in , and the selected bond lengths and angles were listed in Table S2.

Compound 1 exhibits a 3D framework crystallizing in the orthorhombic space group Pnnm, with two independent cobalt atoms, half a L4– ligand, one μ4-O2– anionic ligand, and one water ligand in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Co1 with an octahedral geometry is surrounded by four carboxylate O atoms, one water O atom, and one μ4-O2– anion, which is disordered near the c axis, while the Co2 is surrounded by four carboxylate O atoms and one μ4-O2– anion to form a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. Two Co1 and two Co2 atoms are bridged by eight carboxylates of six L4– ligands and one μ4-O2– anion to form a [Co4O­(COO)8] cluster with the Co–O distances of 1.998 to 2.237 Å (b). All carboxylates in L4– exhibit bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2) coordination modes (Figure S1). Six [Co4O­(COO)8] clusters and six L4– ligands interlink to form an M6L6 octahedral cage with a diameter of 12.93 Å and a window size of 6.1 × 9.2 Å2 (excluding van der Waals radii of the atoms) (b). The face-transitive tiling of the cage is shown in Figure S2. The neighboring cages are joined together further to generate 3D microporous MOFs (c). Along the a axis, adjacent cages share the windows to form 1D channels (Figure S3). Removing guest molecules, the framework has a free void of 48.5%, calculated with PLATON program (d). Topologically, by regarding [Co4O­(COO)8] cluster and L4– ligand as 6- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, 1 can be simplified as a binodal (3,6)-connected rtl net with the point symbol of (4·62)2(42·610·83) (Figure S4).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 

Compound 1 exhibits a 3D framework crystallizing in the orthorhombic space group Pnnm, with two independent cobalt atoms, half a L4- ligand, one μ4-O2- anionic ligand, and one water ligand in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Co1 with an octahedral geometry is surrounded by four carboxylate O atoms, one water O atom, and one μ4-O2- anion, which is disordered near the c axis, while the Co2 is surrounded by four carboxylate O atoms and one μ4-O2- anion to form a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. Two Co1 and two Co2 atoms are bridged by eight carboxylates of six L4- ligands and one μ4-O2- anion to form a [Co4O(COO)8] cluster with the Co-O distances of 1.998 to 2.237 Å (b). All carboxylates in L4- exhibit bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2) coordination modes (Figure S1). Six [Co4O(COO)8] clusters and six L4- ligands interlink to form an M6L6 octahedral cage with a diameter of 12.93 Å and a window size of 6.1 × 9.2 Å2 (excluding van der Waals radii of the atoms) (b). The face-transitive tiling of the cage is shown in Figure S2. The neighboring cages are joined together further to generate 3D microporous MOFs (c). Along the a axis, adjacent cages share the windows to form 1D channels (Figure S3). Removing guest molecules, the framework has a free void of 48.5%, calculated with PLATON program (d). Topologically, by regarding [Co4O(COO)8] cluster and L4- ligand as 6- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, 1 can be simplified as a binodal (3,6)-connected  rtl  net with the point symbol of (4⋅62)2(42⋅610⋅83) (Figure S4).

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphic with the same triclinic space group P1̅. The structure of 2 is taken as an example to be analyzed. In 2, one asymmetry unit contains two L4– ligands and two and a half independent zinc atoms. As shown in a, Zn1 is six-coordinated with six O atoms from four carboxylate groups of two L4– ligands. One Zn3 and two Zn2 atoms are bridged by six carboxylates to form a centrosymmetric linear trinuclear [Zn3(COO)6] cluster (b) in which the central Zn3 atom with an octahedral geometry is surround by six carboxylate O atoms, while the two outer Zn2 atoms are all ligated by six carboxylate O atoms, forming distorted octahedral geometries. There are two different coordination modes of L4– ligands (L4–-I and L4–-II) in 2 (Figure S5). One Zn1 links one L4–-I and one L4–-II to form a four-connected node, then the node connects [Zn3(COO)6] clusters to afford a 3D framework (c). Using PLATON program, the solvent-free void of 60.3% was calculated. To better understand the structure of compound 2, the network was parsed in a different way. As shown in d, the Zn1 with two L4– ligands forms a four-connected node, which connects the eight-connected [Zn3(COO)6] cluster to afford a 4,8-connected flu network with the point symbol of (46)2(412·612·84) (f), which was only reported in scarce MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 2 and 3 

Compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphic with the same triclinic space group P1̅. The structure of 2 is taken as an example to be analyzed. In 2, one asymmetry unit contains two L4- ligands and two and a half independent zinc atoms. As shown in a, Zn1 is six-coordinated with six O atoms from four carboxylate groups of two L4- ligands. One Zn3 and two Zn2 atoms are bridged by six carboxylates to form a centrosymmetric linear trinuclear [Zn3(COO)6] cluster (b) in which the central Zn3 atom with an octahedral geometry is surround by six carboxylate O atoms, while the two outer Zn2 atoms are all ligated by six carboxylate O atoms, forming distorted octahedral geometries. There are two different coordination modes of L4- ligands (L4--I and L4--II) in 2 (Figure S5). One Zn1 links one L4--I and one L4--II to form a four-connected node, then the node connects [Zn3(COO)6] clusters to afford a 3D framework (c). Using PLATON program, the solvent-free void of 60.3% was calculated. To better understand the structure of compound 2, the network was parsed in a different way. As shown in d, the Zn1 with two L4- ligands forms a four-connected node, which connects the eight-connected [Zn3(COO)6] cluster to afford a 4,8-connected  flu  network with the point symbol of (46)2(412⋅612⋅84) (f), which was only reported in scarce MOFs.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that complexes 2 and 3 are isostructural anioic frameworks with the free voids of 61.2% and 60.3%, respectively. These features encourage us to employ 3 as a carrier for Eu3+ ions. After soaking the fresh sample of 3 in Eu3+ solution for 72 h at 60 °C, Eu3+ ions were successfully loaded into 3, yielding Eu@3 (). ICP analysis reveals that Eu3+ ions were successfully fixed in the channels, and the molar ratio of Eu3+/Cd2+ is 0.48 (Table S3). Meanwhile, the loading of Eu3+ does not influence the crystalline integrity of 3 as demonstrated by PXRD (Figure S6d).

elements.content: The experimental PXRD patterns of 1–3 and Eu@3 are in agreement with the simulated ones from the single-crystal structures (Figure S6), indicating the phase purity. TGA of 1–3 and Eu@3 were performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C. Compound 1 indicates a weight loss of 23.3% (calcd 23.3%) in the temperature range of 30–272 °C, resulting from the removal of all DMA and H2O guest molecules (Figure S7a). Compound 2 shows two weight-loss steps from 30 to 180 °C (7.8%) and 180–270 °C (8.5%), corresponding to the removal of all lattice water and NMP molecules (calcd 16.3%) (Figure S7b). Compound 3 reveals a 24.2% (calcd 24.1%) weight loss from 30 to 185 °C, corresponding to the removal of all DMF and water guest molecules. Subsequently, no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework collapsed at 300 °C (Figure S7c). Eu@3 possesses a 25.2% (calcd 25.1%) weight loss from 30 to 190 °C, and no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework collapsed at 320 °C (Figure S7d). Notably, Eu@3 reveals more weight residuals (24.0%) compared to that of 3 (10.0%), being consistent with the loading of Eu3+ ions in 3.

Compound 3 reveals a 24.2% (calcd 24.1%) weight loss from 30 to 185 °C, corresponding to the removal of all DMF and water guest molecules. Subsequently, no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework collapsed at 300 °C (Figure S7c). Eu@3 possesses a 25.2% (calcd 25.1%) weight loss from 30 to 190 °C, and no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework collapsed at 320 °C (Figure S7d). elements.content: To assess the porosity by gas adsorption measurements, 1 was activated by soaking a sample in CH2Cl2 for 36 h and then heating under vacuum at 150 °C for 5 h. TGA and PXRD confirm the removal of all guest molecules and the framework intactness, respectively (Figure S8). However, we failed to obtain the activated frameworks of 2 and 3 with structural integrity. The activated 1 reveals a minimum N2 loading at 77 K, but more CO2 and CH4 loading of 57.5 and 21.2 cm3 (STP) g–1 at 195 K and 1 bar, respectively (a). The type-I sorption isotherm of CO2 at 195 K confirms microporous material of 1, from which the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 166.5 cm2 g–1, Langmuir surface area of 203.4 cm2 g–1, and a mean pore width of 6.8 Å based on Horvath–Kawazoe mode were obtained (Figure S9), respectively.

Gas Adsorption

To assess the porosity by gas adsorption measurements, 1 was activated by soaking a sample in CH2Cl2 for 36 h and then heating under vacuum at 150 °C for 5 h. TGA and PXRD confirm the removal of all guest molecules and the framework intactness, respectively (Figure S8). However, we failed to obtain the activated frameworks of 2 and 3 with structural integrity. The activated 1 reveals a minimum N2 loading at 77 K, but more CO2 and CH4 loading of 57.5 and 21.2 cm3 (STP) g-1 at 195 K and 1 bar, respectively (a). The type-I sorption isotherm of CO2 at 195 K confirms microporous material of 1, from which the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of 166.5 cm2 g-1, Langmuir surface area of 203.4 cm2 g-1, and a mean pore width of 6.8 Å based on Horvath-Kawazoe mode were obtained (Figure S9), respectively.

elements.content: The uptake capacities of CO2, CH4, and N2 gases were also measured at 298 K. Compound 1 shows no loading of N2 (the adsorption amount is too low to be detected by our instrument) and low loading of CH4 (7.3 cm3 (STP) g–1), but a remarkable CO2 uptake of 22.1 cm3 g–1 at 1 bar (b). The significant difference in the adsorption amounts of CO2 and CH4 reveals considerable selectivity for CO2 over CH4 in 1. To predict the CO2/CH4 selectivity in 1 for CO2–CH4 binary mixture, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was employed on the basis of the experimental adsorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 at 298 K (Figure S10). For CO2–CH4 mixtures with general feed compositions of landfill gas (CO2/CH4 = 50:50) and natural gas (CO2/CH4 = 10:90), the calculated CO2/CH4 selectivity values at 1 bar are 10.0 and 8.5, respectively (). The values are even higher compared to the known functionalized MOFs with the good CO2/CH4 selectivity results (). The significant sorption selectivity for CO2 over CH4 may be contributed to the moderate affinity resulting from the C–H···O hydrogen bonds between the phenyl −CH groups of framework and CO2 molecules in the channels. In addition, the adsorption affinity of 1 for CO2 was evaluated by the isosteric heat (Q st) with the virial equation based on the adsorption isotherms of CO2 at 273.15 and 298 K (Figure S11a). The initial Q st is 30.1 kJ mol–1 (Figure S11b), which is relatively higher and comparable with the reported values in other MOFs with various activated sites (Table S4), reflecting the stronger framework–CO2 interactions. Therefore, 1 can be regarded as a promising material in postcombustion CO2 capture, biogas treatment, and natural gas clean up.

At room temperature, the solid-state luminescence of H4L and Eu@3 was studied and recorded in Figure S12. H4L shows the strongest emission at 395 nm at an excitation of 348 nm. The excitation spectrum of Eu@3, monitored at the characteristic emission (614 nm) of the Eu3+ ions, exhibits a broad band with the absorption at 395 nm, indicating the presence of energy transfer from the ligand to Eu3+ ions. Under this excitation, the four characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ ion at 592, 614, 653, and 696 nm were observed, which originate from 5D0–7F0, 5D0–7F1, 5D0–7F2, and 5D0–7F3 f–f transitions of Eu3+ ion, respectively. In addition, under UV irradiation, Eu@3 displays bright red luminescence, which can be regarded as a qualitative indication of Eu3+ sensitization.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

At room temperature, the solid-state luminescence of H4L and Eu@3 was studied and recorded in Figure S12. H4L shows the strongest emission at 395 nm at an excitation of 348 nm. The excitation spectrum of Eu@3, monitored at the characteristic emission (614 nm) of the Eu3+ ions, exhibits a broad band with the absorption at 395 nm, indicating the presence of energy transfer from the ligand to Eu3+ ions. Under this excitation, the four characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ ion at 592, 614, 653, and 696 nm were observed, which originate from 5D0-7F0, 5D0-7F1, 5D0-7F2, and 5D0-7F3 f-f transitions of Eu3+ ion, respectively. In addition, under UV irradiation, Eu@3 displays bright red luminescence, which can be regarded as a qualitative indication of Eu3+ sensitization.

elements.content: In light of the intense luminescence, Eu@3 is evaluated as a potential luminescent sensor for metal ions. A five milligram sample of Eu@3 was dispersed in 3 mL of DMF solution (0.1 M) containing different kinds of metal ions (M­(NO3) n (M = Li+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Al3+, Fe3+) for luminescent sensing studies. As shown in a, the metal ions all have an effect on the luminescent intensity of Eu@3. However, the luminescent change incurred by Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions relative to other cations can be clearly observed, the luminescence of Eu@3 was almost quenched. The results suggest high selectivity of Eu@3 for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions. The concentration-dependent luminescent measurements for the two metal ions were further carried out to estimate the sensitivity of Eu@3 for the two metal ions (a,b). Obviously, with the increasing of concentrations of Cu2+ and Fe3+ ions, the emissive intensity of Eu@3 at 615 nm is gradually decreased. For Cu2+ ion, the plot of I 0/I vs [M] ([M] = the concentration of metal ion) can be well fitted by the Stern–Volmer equation I 0/I = 0.99+ K sv [M] (a) (I 0 and I are the luminescent intensities of Eu@3 in the absence and presence of metal ion, respectively, K sv represents quenching rate constant). The K sv value is calculated to about 501.2, which is comparable with or better than those previously reported well-designed compounds for sensing Cu2+ ions. The limit of detection (LOD) determined following the 3δ IUPAC criteria can reach 7.12 × 10–3 M. For Fe3+ ion, the plot of I 0/I vs [M] can be fitted by I 0/I = 0.417 × exp­([Fe3+]/6.06) + 0.639, and the linear correlation only occurs at low concentrations (b and S13a), indicating the coexistence of the dynamic and static quenching processes. The calculated detection limit for Fe3+ ion can reach as low as 3.20 × 10–3 M, comparable with the reported values in some Ln-MOFs. The low detection limit implying the promise of Eu@3 for the sensitive and selective detection of Cu2+ and Fe3+ ions.

elements.content: For a luminescent sensor in applications, the fast and simple recycling performance is required. The recycled sample of Eu@3 obtained by washing with DMF solutions several times was studied by luminescence and PXRD. It found that after five cycles of experiments the luminescent intensity of Eu@3 was almost unchanged compared to the initial state of Eu@3 in Cu2+/Fe3+ solution (), and the framework structure is still intact (Figure S14). Hence, Eu@3 as a sensor for Cu2+/Fe3+ ion reveals good stability and recyclability.

elements.content: It is well-known that the luminescent intensity of Ln3+ relies on the efficiency of the antenna effect. Cu2+ and Fe3+ ions show negligible photon-absorption at 300 nm, so there is no clear evidence for competitive adsorption between Cu2+/Fe3+ ion and Eu@3. However, the concentration of Cu2+/Fe3+ ion and the luminescent intensity all indicated the dynamic mechanism in the quenching process. Therefore, the quenching mechanism is probably attributed to the collision interactions between the framework and metal ions, which decreases the efficiency of intersystem crossing 1pp*–3pp* and reduces the efficiency of ligand-to-Eu energy transfer, further leading to the quenching effect on the luminescence of Eu3+ ion.

Therefore, the quenching mechanism is probably attributed to the collision interactions between the framework and metal ions, which decreases the efficiency of intersystem crossing 1pp*-3pp* and reduces the efficiency of ligand-to-Eu energy transfer, further leading to the quenching effect on the luminescence of Eu3+ ion.

elements.content: Simultaneously, a 5 mg sample of Eu@3 was dispersed in 3 mL of DMF solution (0.1 M) containing different kinds of anions for luminescent sensing studies. As illustrated in b, the luminescent intensity of the various suspensions mainly depends on the types of contained anions. Uniquely, Cr2O7 2– ion completely quenches the luminescence of Eu@3, indicating the sensing potential of Eu@3 for Cr2O7 2– ion. Quantitative experiment indicates that the luminescence of Eu@3 was gradually reduced with the increasing of the concentration of the Cr2O7 2– ion, and the luminescent intensity obeys equation I 0/I = 0.783 × exp­([Cr2O7 2–]/0.361) + 0.845 along with the coexistence of the dynamic and static quenching processes, and the detection limit of 5.42 × 10–4 M was also obtained based on 3δ IUPAC criteria (c and S13b). Meanwhile, the recycle experiment shows Eu@3 also can be reused in Cr2O7 2– ion sensing (). Similar to the Fe3+ ion, the possible quenching mechanism for Cr2O7 2– ion may also result from that the introduction of Cr2O7 2– ion consumes the energy through the collision interactions and decreases the energy transfer from ligand to Eu3+, causing the luminescent quenching.

elements.content: In summary, four MOFs based on a V-shaped rigid multicarboxylates ligand have been synthesized and characterized. Compound 1 is a 3D porous framework based on an unprecedented M6L6 octahedral cage constituted by six [Co4O­(COO)8] clusters and six L4– ligands, presenting a (3,6)-connected rtl net and revealing high selective adsorption for CO2 over CH4 as well. Compounds 2, 3, and Eu@3 are isomorphic frameworks with a rare 4,8-connected flu net based on [Zn3(COO)6] clusters. Importantly, Eu@3 not only is an unprecedented recyclable Ln-MOF sensor for Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2– ions with good recyclability but also represents a rare example that prepares a Ln-MOF sensor by the postsynthetic loading of Ln3+ ions into the anionic MOFs through the cationic exchange. The presented novel structures and remarkable potential applications may offer one practical assembly method for functional MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, four MOFs based on a V-shaped rigid multicarboxylates ligand have been synthesized and characterized. Compound 1 is a 3D porous framework based on an unprecedented M6L6 octahedral cage constituted by six [Co4O(COO)8] clusters and six L4- ligands, presenting a (3,6)-connected  rtl  net and revealing high selective adsorption for CO2 over CH4 as well. Compounds 2, 3, and Eu@3 are isomorphic frameworks with a rare 4,8-connected  flu  net based on [Zn3(COO)6] clusters. Importantly, Eu@3 not only is an unprecedented recyclable Ln-MOF sensor for Cu2+, Fe3+, and Cr2O7 2- ions with good recyclability but also represents a rare example that prepares a Ln-MOF sensor by the postsynthetic loading of Ln3+ ions into the anionic MOFs through the cationic exchange. The presented novel structures and remarkable potential applications may offer one practical assembly method for functional MOFs.

The bottle was heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C min–1. Purple block crystals of 1 were obtained in 50.4% yield. Anal. A mixture of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.0287 g, 0.1 mmol), H4L (0.0203 g, 0.05 mmol), NMP (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and CH3CN (0.5 mL) was sealed in a 10 mL glass bottle. The bottle was heated at 105 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C min–1. Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained in 49.1% yield. Anal. Calcd for C49H42Zn2.5NO22: C, 50.72; H, 3.65; N, 1.21%. Found: C, 50.85; H, 3.76; N, 1.28%. A mixture of CdCl2·2H2O (0.0228 g, 0.1 mmol), H4L (0.0203 g, 0.05 mmol), DMF (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and CH3CN (0.5 mL) was sealed in a 10 mL glass bottle. Synthesis of <bold>Eu@3</bold>

A mixture of 3 (0.143 g, 0.1 mmol), Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and CH3CN (0.5 mL) was sealed in a 10 mL glass bottle. The bottle was sealed and heated at 60 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C min–1. Colorless block crystals of Eu@3 were obtained. ICP Anal. Calcd (%): Eu, 32.35; Cd, 67.65%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3069 (s), 2929 (w), 2491­(w), 1660 (s), 1585 (s), 1494 (m), 1401 (s), 1365 (m), 1249 (m), 1103 (s), 840 (m), 777 (s), 703 (m), 667­(m), 522­(w).

cln_elements.content:
It is noteworthy that complexes 2 and 3 are isostructural anioic frameworks with the free voids of 61.2% and 60.3%, respectively. These features encourage us to employ 3 as a carrier for Eu3+ ions. After soaking the fresh sample of 3 in Eu3+ solution for 72 h at 60 °C, Eu3+ ions were successfully loaded into 3, yielding Eu@3 (). ICP analysis reveals that Eu3+ ions were successfully fixed in the channels, and the molar ratio of Eu3+/Cd2+ is 0.48 (Table S3). Meanwhile, the loading of Eu3+ does not influence the crystalline integrity of 3 as demonstrated by PXRD (Figure S6d).

PXRD and TGA

The experimental PXRD patterns of 1–3 and Eu@3 are in agreement with the simulated ones from the single-crystal structures (Figure S6), indicating the phase purity. TGA of 1–3 and Eu@3 were performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 700 °C. Compound 1 indicates a weight loss of 23.3% (calcd 23.3%) in the temperature range of 30–272 °C, resulting from the removal of all DMA and H2O guest molecules (Figure S7a). Compound 2 shows two weight-loss steps from 30 to 180 °C (7.8%) and 180–270 °C (8.5%), corresponding to the removal of all lattice water and NMP molecules (calcd 16.3%) (Figure S7b). Compound 3 reveals a 24.2% (calcd 24.1%) weight loss from 30 to 185 °C, corresponding to the removal of all DMF and water guest molecules. Subsequently, no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework collapsed at 300 °C (Figure S7c). Eu@3 possesses a 25.2% (calcd 25.1%) weight loss from 30 to 190 °C, and no obvious weight loss is observed until the framework collapsed at 320 °C (Figure S7d). Notably, Eu@3 reveals more weight residuals (24.0%) compared to that of 3 (10.0%), being consistent with the loading of Eu3+ ions in 3.

Gas Adsorption

To assess the porosity by gas adsorption measurements, 1 was activated by soaking a sample in CH2Cl2 for 36 h and then heating under vacuum at 150 °C for 5 h. TGA and PXRD confirm the removal of all guest molecules and the framework intactness, respectively (Figure S8). However, we failed to obtain the activated frameworks of 2 and 3 with structural integrity. The activated 1 reveals a minimum N2 loading at 77 K, but more CO2 and CH4 loading of 57.5 and 21.2 cm3 (STP) g–1 at 195 K and 1 bar, respectively (a). The type-I sorption isotherm of CO2 at 195 K confirms microporous material of 1, from which the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of 166.5 cm2 g–1, Langmuir surface area of 203.4 cm2 g–1, and a mean pore width of 6.8 Å based on Horvath–Kawazoe mode were obtained (Figure S9), respectively.

The uptake capacities of CO2, CH4, and N2 gases were also measured at 298 K. Compound 1 shows no loading of N2 (the adsorption amount is too low to be detected by our instrument) and low loading of CH4 (7.3 cm3 (STP) g–1), but a remarkable CO2 uptake of 22.1 cm3 g–1 at 1 bar (b). The significant difference in the adsorption amounts of CO2 and CH4 reveals considerable selectivity for CO2 over CH4 in 1. To predict the CO2/CH4 selectivity in 1 for CO2–CH4 binary mixture, the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was employed on the basis of the experimental adsorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 at 298 K (Figure S10). For CO2–CH4 mixtures with general feed compositions of landfill gas (CO2/CH4 = 50:50) and natural gas (CO2/CH4 = 10:90), the calculated CO2/CH4 selectivity values at 1 bar are 10.0 and 8.5, respectively (). The values are even higher compared to the known functionalized MOFs with the good CO2/CH4 selectivity results (). The significant sorption selectivity for CO2 over CH4 may be contributed to the moderate affinity resulting from the C–H···O hydrogen bonds between the phenyl −CH groups of framework and CO2 molecules in the channels. In addition, the adsorption affinity of 1 for CO2 was evaluated by the isosteric heat (Q st) with the virial equation based on the adsorption isotherms of CO2 at 273.15 and 298 K (Figure S11a). The initial Q st is 30.1 kJ mol–1 (Figure S11b), which is relatively higher and comparable with the reported values in other MOFs with various activated sites (Table S4), reflecting the stronger framework–CO2 interactions. Therefore, 1 can be regarded as a promising material in postcombustion CO2 capture, biogas treatment, and natural gas clean up.

metadata.title:
Four New 3D Metal–Organic Frameworks Constructed
by a V‑shaped Tetracarboxylates Ligand: Selective CO2 Sorption and Luminescent Sensing
